Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Cryoprobe for a 600 MHz NMR Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor James Nowick from the University of California Irvine and colleagues Vy Dong and Christopher Vanderwal will acquire a cryoprobe (broad band and fluorine observe, BBFO) that will be installed on a 600 MHz NMR spectrometer. This attachment will greatly increase the sensitivity of the spectrometer at a fraction of the cost of new spectrometer and will allow research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as the study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research by postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate students at the University of California at Irvine and will also impact outreach activities involving K-12 programs that target schools with predominantly minority populations.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) developing mechanisms and metal-catalyzed methods; (b) catalytic hydroacylation; (c) designing molecules and materials that capture carbon monoxide; (d) synthesizing linked aza-phenanthrenes; (e) developing new approaches for stereoselective formation of quaternary carbon stereocenters and fragment coupling; (f) synthesizing batrachotoxin and its analogues; and (g) chemical synthesis of complex bioactive natural products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project upgraded one of the four nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometers in the Department of Chemistry at UC Irvine with a high sensitivity cryoprobe.
NMR spectroscopy is used to determine the structures of molecules that researchers are studying and to analyze other properties, such as the rates of chemical reactions. NMR is an extremely valuable analytical technique, but has inherent low sensitivity.This places limits both on the minimum sample quantity that can be examined and the complexity of experiments that can be completed within a reasonable time-frame.
The UCI NMR Facility services over 300 active users from around 40 research groups, and so instrument time is at a premium. Many of the users are graduate students, who are earning their doctorates, or undergraduates, who are doing research. The facility not only helps advance the research of these students, but also contributes to their training as scientists.
A conventional NMR spectrometer consists of a superconducting magnet but with a probehead at room temperature. The probehead contains the most sensitive electronics for signal detection. A cryoprobe is a probehead cooled to cryogenic temperatures by helium gas. This dramatically reduces the background electronic noise and thus increases the sensitivity.
The NMR spectrometer in question operates at 600 MHz. The gain in sensitivity resulting from the cryoprobe upgrade is between four and five times, depending on the type of experiment in use.
This extra capability has many benefits:The price of a cryoprobe upgrade is less than half of that of a complete instrument with a conventional probe, yet the capacity for sample analysis is multiplied four to five times. Increased sensitivity means both that signals from smaller samples can be detected, and data quality from existing sample sizes can be achieved in a fraction of the experiment time.
The new 600 MHz cryoprobe has the capability to observe most NMR active nuclei and is equipped with automatic adjustment of tuning and matching for optimum performance. Thus far, nuclei observed include proton, deuterium, boron-11, carbon-13, nitrogen-15, fluorine-19, silicon-29, phosphorus-31, vanadium-51 and cobalt-59. Experiments employed have acquired one-dimensional and two-dimensional spectra for structural analysis of a wide range of chemical compounds.


Last Modified: 09/03/2017
Modified by: James S Nowick
